member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingCoreModule
member.summary:
Represents the KGySoft.Drawing.Core module.
See the Remarks section of the Initialize method for details.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingCoreModule.Initialize
member.summary: Initializes the KGySoft.Drawing.Core module. It initializes the resource manager for string resources and registers its central management in the LanguageSettings class.

remarks.note: The module initializer is executed automatically when any member is accessed in the module for the first time. This method is public to able to trigger module initialization without performing any other operation. Normally you don't need to call it explicitly but it can be useful if you use the KGy SOFT Drawing Core Libraries in an application and you want to configure resource management on starting the application via the LanguageSettings class. In such case you can call this method before configuring language settings to make sure that the resources of the KGySoft.Drawing.Core.dll are also affected by the settings.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorSpaceHelper
member.summary: A helper class containing low-level conversion methods for byte, ushort and float types to convert color components using the sRGB and linear color spaces.

member.summary: Converts a byte to a floating-point value between 0 and 1 without changing the color space.
member.param: The value to convert.
member.returns: A floating-point value between 0 and 1.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorSpaceHelper.ToFloat(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Converts a value to a floating-point value between 0 and 1 without changing the color space.
member.param: The value to convert.
member.returns: A floating-point value between 0 and 1.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorSpaceHelper.ToByte(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts a floating-point value ranging from 0 to 1 to a byte without changing the color space. Out-of-range values are allowed in which case the result will be clipped to Byte.MinValue or Byte.MaxValue.
member.param: The value to convert.
member.returns: The result of the conversion.

member.returns: The result of the conversion.

member.returns: The result of the conversion.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorSpaceHelper.ToUInt16(System.Byte)
member.summary: Converts an 8-bit color channel value to a 16-bit value representing the same intensity without changing the color space.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette
member.summary: Represents an indexed set of colors and provides efficient color lookup with caching. To create an instance use the static methods or the constructors.

remarks.para: The class represents an indexed set of colors that can be accessed by the indexer or the GetEntries method.
The class supports performing quick lookup operations (see GetNearestColor and GetNearestColorIndex methods) to find the closest matching palette entry to any color.
remarks.note: The palette entries represent colors in the sRGB color space and nearest color lookup is also performed in the sRGB color space by default but you can create a instance that performs looking up for nearest colors in the linear color space by the constructor or the factory methods that have parameter. See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.
remarks.para: By default the lookup is performed by a slightly modified euclidean-like search but if the contains grayscale entries only, then it is optimized for finding the best matching gray shade based on human perception. To override this logic a custom lookup routine can be passed to the constructors.

If the instance is created without a custom lookup logic, then the search results for non-palette-entry colors are cached. The cache is optimized for parallel processing. The theoretical maximum of cache size (apart from the actual palette entries) is 2 x 218 but as soon as that limit is reached the amount of stored elements are halved so the cache is somewhat optimized to store the most recently processed colors.

In order to prevent caching you can pass a custom lookup logic to the constructors. It is expected to be fast (applying some direct mapping to a palette index, for example), or that it uses some custom caching (which should perform well also when queried concurrently).

The palette can have any number of colors but as the typical usage is quantizing colors for indexed bitmaps the typical maximum palette size is 256. Generally, the more colors the palette has the slower are the lookups for non-palette colors that are not cached yet.

member.threadsafety: If there is no custom lookup logic passed to the constructors, then members of this type are guaranteed to be safe for multi-threaded operations. If this type is initialized with a custom lookup logic, then thread-safety depends on the custom lookup implementation.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of color entries in the current .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.BackColor
member.summary: Gets the background color. If a lookup operation (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex) is performed with a color whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the entries of this , then the color will be blended with this color before performing the lookup.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this has a transparent entry, then gets a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex) in the palette.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.IsGrayscale
member.summary: Gets whether the palette consists of grayscale entries only.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.HasAlpha
member.summary: Gets whether the palette contains at least one entry that is not fully opaque.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary: Gets the preferred color space of this instance for performing blending and measuring distance when looking for a nearest color. You can use the constructor to create a clone of this using a different working color space.

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.
remarks.para: If the value of this property is , then the sRGB color space is used because palette entries represent sRGB colors anyway.
If this palette uses a custom nearest color lookup, then it depends on the custom function whether it considers the value of this property.
remarks.note: Please note that palette entries themselves always represent sRGB color values, regardless the value of this property.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the color entry of this at the specified .
member.param: The index of the color entry to be retrieved.
member.returns: A instance representing the color entry of the at the specified .
member.exception: must be equal to or greater than zero and less .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.#ctor(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32[],KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte,System.Func{KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Int32})
member.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the class.
See the Remarks section of the class for details.
member.param: The color entries to be stored by this instance.

Specifies the background color for lookup operations (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex). When a lookup is performed with a color, whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the , then the color to be found will be blended with this color before performing the lookup. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored.

If there is at least one completely transparent color among , then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex).

A delegate specifying an optional custom lookup logic to obtain an index from by a instance. If specified, it must be thread-safe and it is expected to be fast. The results returned by the specified delegate are not cached. If , then GetNearestColor and GetNearestColorIndex methods will perform a sequential lookup by using a default logic and results will be cached.

The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

If there is at least one completely transparent color among , then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex). This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

A delegate specifying an optional custom lookup logic to obtain an index from by a and an instance. If specified, it must be thread-safe and it is expected to be fast. The results returned by the specified delegate are not cached. Make sure you always obtain the palette properties such as , and from the argument as this delegate can be re-used in another instance when calling the constructor. If , then GetNearestColor and GetNearestColorIndex methods will perform a sequential lookup by using a default logic and results will be cached. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Palette.SystemDefault8BppPalette(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary:
Gets a instance that uses the system default 8-bit palette. This palette contains the 16 standard basic sRGB colors, the "web-safe" palette of 216 colors as well as 24 transparent entries.
See the Remarks section of the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.SystemDefault8BppPalette method for details and some examples.
member.param:
Specifies the background color for lookup operations (GetNearestColor, GetNearestColorIndex). When a lookup is performed with a color, whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the palette entries, then the color to be found will be blended with this color before performing the lookup. The Color32.A field of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color (GetNearestColor) or the index of the first transparent color (GetNearestColorIndex). This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that uses the system default 8-bit palette.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData(System.Drawing.Size,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte)
member.summary: Creates an instance with the specified and .
member.param: The size of the bitmap data to create in pixels.
The desired pixel format of the bitmap data to create.

Specifies the preferred color space that should be used when working with the result bitmap data.
See the Remarks section of the enumeration for more details.

For pixel formats without alpha gradient support specifies the value of the returned instance. It does not affect the actual returned bitmap content. See the Remarks section for details. The alpha value (Color32.A field) of the specified background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

For pixel formats without alpha gradient support specifies the value of the returned instance. See the Remarks section for details. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: An instance with the specified and .

remarks.para: This method supports predefined pixel formats. To create a bitmap data with some custom pixel format use the overloads that have parameters.
The parameter has no effect if has alpha gradient support and it does not affect the actual content of the returned instance. To set all pixels to a color use the Clear extension method.

If is zero, then setting a fully transparent pixel in a bitmap data with indexed or single-bit-alpha pixel format will blend the pixel to set with even if the bitmap data can handle transparent pixels.

If is 1, then the result color of setting a pixel of a bitmap data with indexed or single-bit-alpha pixel format will be transparent only if the color to set is completely transparent (has zero alpha).

If is 255, then the result color of setting a pixel of a bitmap data with indexed or single-bit-alpha pixel format will be opaque only if the color to set is completely opaque (its alpha value is 255).
For s without any alpha support the specified is used only to determine the source pixels to skip when another bitmap data is drawn into the returned instance.

If a pixel of a bitmap data without alpha gradient support is set by the IWritableBitmapData.SetPixel/IWritableBitmapDataRow.SetColor methods or by the IReadWriteBitmapDataRow indexer, and the pixel has an alpha value that is greater than , then the pixel to set will be blended with .

The parameter indicates the preferred color space when working with the result bitmap data. Blending operations performed by this library (eg. by IWritableBitmapData.SetPixel when blending is necessary as described above, or by the DrawInto extension methods) respect the value of this parameter. Blending in the linear color space produces natural results but the operation is a bit slower if the actual pixel format is not in the linear color space, and the result is different from the results of most applications including popular image processors and web browsers. See the Remarks section of the enumeration for more details.

list.item: If represents an indexed format you can use the overload to specify the desired palette of the result.

To create an instance from a platform specific bitmap type such as Bitmap or WriteableBitmap, use the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension methods for various platform dependent bitmap implementations. See the Remarks section of the namespace for a list about the technologies with dedicated support, and the Remarks section of the BitmapExtensions.GetReadWriteBitmapData method for details and code samples. That method is for the GDI+ Bitmap type but the main principles apply for all sources.

remarks.para: This method allows creating an instance with custom pixel format. You need to specify a and a pair of delegates that are called whenever a pixel is get or set.
A custom pixel format can have any value between 1 and 128. A typical bits-per-pixel value is a power of two; however, any other value can be used if you handle them in the provided delegates.

The and delegates are called whenever a pixel is needed to be get or set. The delegates are always called with an x coordinate meaning the pixel offset in the corresponding row. The delegates must not use the directly. They must access the actual data using their argument, which allows reading and writing raw data within the corresponding row.

member.typeparam: The type of the elements in .
member.param: A preallocated array to be used as the underlying buffer for the returned . It can be larger than it is required for the specified parameters. If the actual image data starts at some offset use the overload instead.

Specifies the desired of the returned instance. It determines also the and properties of the result. This parameter is optional.

A delegate to be called when the palette is attempted to be replaced by the TrySetPalette method. If belongs to some custom bitmap implementation, it can be used to update its original palette. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

A delegate to be called when the returned is disposed or finalized. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An instance wrapping the specified and using the provided parameters.

remarks.para: This method allows creating an instance with a custom indexed pixel format. You need to specify a and a pair of delegates that are called whenever a pixel is get or set.

An indexed custom pixel format can have any value between 1 and 16. A typical bits-per-pixel value is a power of two and is not greater than 8; however, any other value can be used if you handle them in the provided delegates.

The and delegates are called whenever a pixel is needed to be get or set. The delegates are always called with an x coordinate meaning the pixel offset in the corresponding row. The delegates must not use the directly. They must access the actual data using their argument, which allows reading and writing raw data within the corresponding row.

If is , then the closest not larger system palette will be used, possibly completed with transparent entries. For example, if PixelFormatInfo.BitsPerPixel is 9 and is , then a with 512 colors will be created where the first 256 colors will be the same as in SystemDefault8BppPalette. For that reason it is always recommended to set the parameter, especially if it has fewer entries than the possible allowed maximum because replacing the palette afterwards by the TrySetPalette extension method allows only to set a palette that has no fewer entries. It's because the TrySetPalette method assumes that the underlying buffer might already have pixels whose indices may turn invalid with a smaller palette.

member.param: The memory address to be used as the underlying buffer for the returned . Make sure there is enough allocated memory for the specified , and ; otherwise, accessing pixels may corrupt memory or throw an . If it points to managed memory make sure it is pinned until the returned bitmap data is disposed.

The size of a row in bytes. It allows to have some padding at the end of each row. It can be negative for bottom-up layout (ie. when points to the first pixel of the bottom row).

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer
member.summary: Provides an implementation for error diffusion dithering. Use the static properties of this class to use predefined error diffusion filters or the constructor to create a custom one.

remarks.para: The constructor can be used to create an error diffusion ditherer using a custom matrix.
Use the static properties to obtain an instance with predefined parameters.

The class uses an adaptive dithering technique, which disperses the quantization error of each pixels to the neighboring ones. Thereby the strength of the dithering is automatically adjusted by the algorithm itself, which provides good results also for palettes with uneven color distribution (which is not the case for ordered dithering, for example).
As the dithered result of a pixel depends on the already processed pixels, the does not support parallel processing, which makes it slower than most of the other dithering methods.

The following table demonstrates the effect of the dithering:
Original image
Quantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette, no dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Sierra 3 dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Stevenson-Arce dithering
Grayscale color shades
Quantizing with black and white palette, no dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Sierra 3 dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Stevenson-Arce dithering

Calculation of the quantization error may happen in two ways. The publicly available algorithms usually calculate the error for each color channels, which usually provides good results with color palettes. However, when quantizing color images with a black and white or grayscale palette, this approach may fail. For example, if the quantizer returns black for a fully saturated blue pixel, the quantization error is zero on the red and green channels and 100% on the blue channel. The problem is that this error cannot be propagated to the neighboring pixels if they have the same color because adding any more blue to already fully saturated blue pixels will not change anything. Therefore, the can propagate quantization error by brightness based on human perception, which is more appropriate for palettes with grayscale colors. The tries to auto detect the strategy for each dithering session but this can be overridden by the ConfigureErrorDiffusionMode method.

The following table demonstrates the effect of different strategies:
Original image
Quantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using error diffusion by RGB channels (the default strategy for non-grayscale palettes)
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using error diffusion by brightness
Color wheel
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using blue background and error diffusion by brightness (the default strategy for grayscale palettes). All colors appear in the result with different patterns.
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using blue background and error diffusion by RGB channels. The fully saturated colors turned completely black or white.

A typical artifact of error diffusion dithering is a ripple effect, which often appears in homogeneous areas of the dithered image. This is due to the fact that most filters propagate quantization errors mostly to right and down, whereas pixels are processed left-to-right in each line while lines are scanned top-down (raster processing). The ripple effect can be reduced if every second line is processed in the opposite direction (serpentine processing). You can use the ConfigureProcessingDirection method to obtain an with serpentine processing mode, which processes even lines left-to-right and odd lines right-to-left.

The following table demonstrates the effect of different processing directions:
Original image
Quantized image
Original test image "Cameraman"
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using raster processing. The ripple effect is clearly visible on the coat.
Quantizing with black and white palette and Floyd-Steinberg dithering, using serpentine processing. The ripple effect is gone.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the static properties for more examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.FloydSteinberg
member.summary: Gets an instance using the original filter proposed by Floyd and Steinberg in 1975 when they came out with the idea of error diffusion dithering. Uses a small, 3x2 matrix so the processing is somewhat faster than by the other alternatives.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.JarvisJudiceNinke
member.summary: Gets an instance using the filter proposed by Jarvis, Judice and Ninke in 1976. Uses a 5x3 matrix so the processing is slower than by the original Floyd-Steinberg filter but distributes errors in a wider range.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Stucki
member.summary: Gets an instance using the filter proposed by P. Stucki in 1981. Uses a 5x3 matrix so the processing is slower than by the original Floyd-Steinberg filter but distributes errors in a wider range.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Burkes
member.summary: Gets an instance using the filter proposed by D. Burkes in 1988. Uses a 5x2 matrix, which is actually the same as the first two lines of the matrix used by the filter.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Sierra3
member.summary: Gets an instance using the three-line filter proposed by Frankie Sierra in 1989. Uses a 5x3 matrix so this is the slowest Sierra filter but this disperses errors to the furthest among them.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Sierra2
member.summary: Gets an instance using the two-line filter proposed by Frankie Sierra in 1990. Uses a 5x2 matrix so this somewhat faster than the three-line version and still provides a similar quality.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.SierraLite
member.summary: Gets an instance using a small two-line filter proposed by Frankie Sierra. Uses a 3x2 matrix so it has the same performance as the Floyd-Steinberg algorithm and also produces a quite similar result.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.StevensonArce
member.summary: Gets an instance using the hexagonal filter proposed by Stevenson and Arce in 1985. Uses a fairly large, 7x4 matrix, but due to the hexagonal arrangement of the coefficients the processing performance is comparable to a rectangular 5x3 matrix.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ErrorDiffusionDitherer.Atkinson
member.summary: Gets an instance using the filter used by the Apple programmer Bill Atkinson. Uses a 4x3 matrix of only 6 effective values, and propagates only the 75% of the quantization error, which may cause total loss of details of light and dark areas (result may seem under- or overexposed) whereas midtones have higher contrast and preserve details better.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.InterleavedGradientNoiseDitherer
member.summary: Provides an implementation for applying an interleaved gradient noise pattern to the dithered result. For other noise-like ditherers see the OrderedDitherer.BlueNoise property and the class.

remarks.note: The noise generated by the is not random but based on a formula so using the same source image, quantizer and strength produces always the same result (similarly to the ditherer, which is based on ordered dithering). To dither images with real random noise use the , which applies white noise to the quantized source.
remarks.para:
The following table demonstrates the effect of the dithering:

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OrderedDitherer
member.summary: Provides an implementation for dithering patterns that are based on an ordered matrix. Use the static properties of this class to use predefined patterns or the constructor to create a custom ordered ditherer.

remarks.para: The constructor can be used to create an ordered ditherer using a custom matrix.

Use the static properties to obtain an instance with a predefined pattern. For the best results use the Bayer8x8 or BlueNoise properties. Or you can use the DottedHalftone property for artistic results.

The class offers a very fast dithering technique based on an ordered pattern specified in a matrix of bytes. The more different values the matrix has the more number of different patterns can be mapped to the shades of the original pixels. While quantizing lighter and lighter colors, the different patterns appear in the order of the values in the specified matrix.

The following table demonstrates the effect of the dithering:
Original image
Quantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette, no dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and blue noise dithering
Quantizing with system default 8 BPP palette and dotted halftone pattern dithering
Grayscale color shades
Quantizing with black and white palette, no dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and blue noise dithering
Quantizing with black and white palette and dotted halftone pattern dithering

Unlike in case of the , ordered dithering does not adjust strength to the quantization error of a pixel but simply uses the specified matrix values based on pixel coordinates to determine the quantized result. Therefore, a strength can be specified (see the constructor and the ConfigureStrength method), whose ideal value depends on the colors that a quantizer can return. If the strength is too low, then banding may appear in the result in place of gradients in the original image; whereas if the strength is too high, then dithering patterns may appear even in colors without quantization error (overdithering).

Every static property in the returns an instance with auto strength, meaning that strength will be calibrated for each dithering session so that neither the black, nor the white colors will suffer from overdithering in the result.

Auto strength can use different calibration strategies. The default strategy is usually correct if the quantizer returns evenly distributed colors. Otherwise, you can apply the auto strength mode by the ConfigureAutoStrengthMode method that calibrates the strength both for the black and white colors and uses a dynamic strength to each pixel based on its brightness. If none of the auto strength modes provide the desired result you can obtain an instance with custom strength by the ConfigureStrength method.

The following table demonstrates the effect of different strengths:
Original image
Quantized image
Grayscale color shades
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette, no dithering. The asymmetry is due to the uneven distribution of gray shades of this palette.
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering using auto strength. Darker shades have banding.
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering using strength = 0.5. Now there is no banding but white suffers from overdithering.
Quantizing with system default 4 BPP palette and Bayer 8x8 dithering using auto strength strategy. Now there is neither banding nor overdithering for black or white colors.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the static properties for more examples.

member.summary: Provides an implementation for random noise dithering. This class applies a random white noise to the result. For other noise-like ditherers see the OrderedDitherer.BlueNoise property and the class.

remarks.note: There are also a couple of ditherers with non-random noise-like patterns in this library. See also the OrderedDitherer.BlueNoise property and the class.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.ReplaceZeroDelays
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether zero delay values are allowed in the result stream, which is usually interpreted as 100 ms by most GIF decoders.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then zero delay values will be replaced to 100 milliseconds.
If , then zero delays will be preserved and the decoders decide how to interpret them.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.Quantizer
member.summary:
Gets or sets an optional quantizer to be used for the frames. Using a non- value forces the quantization also of already indexed images. Should use up to 256 colors; otherwise, the result might be quantized further with using the default system 8-bit palette.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then the possibly existing palette of already indexed input frames are preserved. For frames with a non-indexed pixel format a quantizer returned by the OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.Wu method will be used.
If not , then all frames will be quantized, even the already indexed ones. If does not support transparency, then will be ignored.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.Ditherer
member.summary:
Gets or sets an optional ditherer to be used when quantizing the frames.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.AnimationMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets the looping mode of the animation.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then the animation will be repeated indefinitely.
If , then the specified frames will be added in both ways so the final animation will be played back and forth.
If , then the animation will be played only once.
The actually supports any positive value less than or equal to UInt16.MaxValue even though they don't have named values in the enumeration.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.EncodeTransparentBorders
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the transparent borders of the frames should be encoded as part of the frame.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then transparent borders of the frames will be considered as image content (and possibly smaller frames will be virtually enlarged, too). This produces a bit larger encoded size but provides better compatibility.
If , then always only the smallest possible non-transparent area will be encoded. Some decoders may not tolerate this option.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.AllowClippedFrames
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the encoder is allowed to add smaller actual frames than the of the animation.
Default value: .
See also the Remarks section of the property for more details.
member.value:
If , then always full-sized frames are added to the animation. This might end up in a larger encoded size but provides better compatibility.
If , then actual frames might be clipped. If is , then it affects only the clipping of possible transparent borders. Some decoders may not tolerate this option.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.AllowDeltaFrames
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether it is allowed to encode only the changed region of a frame. In some circumstances the value of this property might be ignored.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then the required memory during encoding may be larger but it allows creating more compact files and even high color frames (see also the Remarks section).
If , then all frames will be encoded individually. This provides lower memory consumption but may produce larger files.

remarks.para: If is set to an that allows creating a specific palette for each frame, then setting this property to might also allow producing high color frames.
If is , then this property is ignored for quantizers with no transparency support. Therefore make sure that you set also the to if you use a quantizer without transparency support.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.DeltaTolerance
member.summary:
Gets or sets the allowed maximum tolerance for detecting changes of consecutive frames when is .
Default value: 0.
member.value:
If 0, then even a minimal color difference will be considered as a change to be encoded.
If 255, then nothing will be treated as a change. The animation will have no new frames unless a frame contains new transparent pixels compared to the previous one.
The reasonable range is between 0 and 16 with an optimized quantizer. Predefined quantizers may tolerate larger values (eg. up to 32) with some dithering.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimatedGifConfiguration.ReportOverallProgress
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether to report overall and/or sub-task progress when encoding by GifEncoder.BeginEncodeAnimation and GifEncoder.EncodeAnimationAsync methods and the AsyncConfigBase.Progress property is set. When , then both are reported.
Default value: .
member.value:
If , then both overall and sub-task progress are reported. You can filter overall progress steps by considering operations only.
If , then only overall progress steps are reported. Please note that if the count of the instance passed to the constructor cannot be determined in a trivial way, then the maximum value of the steps will be adjusted dynamically.
If , then only sub-task progress steps are reported such as optimizing palette, quantizing and other processing operations.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder
member.summary: Provides an encoder for GIF image format that supports animation. Use the static members for high-level access or create an instance to control everything manually.

remarks.para: The simplest way to create a single-frame GIF image is calling the static EncodeImage method. It can quantize and dither any input source.

The simplest way to create a GIF animation is calling the static EncodeAnimation method. It expects an that describes the frames and delays to be used along with numerous optional configuration such as a specific quantizer and ditherer, looping mode, handling of possible different input image sizes, encoding strategies like allowing delta images or explicitly encoding transparent borders. If you use an and the property is , then you can create really high quality animations allowing more than 256 colors per frame.

Alternatively, you can instantiate the class, which allows you even more control at lower levels. The , and properties should be set before adding the first frame, whereas can be changed before each frame. The AddImage method allows specifying a location for each frame as well as an action to be performed after the delay interval of the corresponding frame is over. You can even write comments to the serialization stream by the AddComments method. When using the AddImage method to add frames you should use already quantized images with indexed pixel format. Non-indexed images will be quantized using the default 8-bit "web-safe" palette without dithering.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.RepeatCount
member.summary:
Gets or sets the number of repetitions if creating an animation. Set a non- value to add the NETSCAPE2.0 extension to the stream and to indicate that added images should be interpreted as animation frames. Use 0 to loop the animation indefinitely. If , and images are added with 0 delay, then GDI+ handles image as a multi-layer single frame image, though some application (including browsers) still may play them as individual frames.
Default value: .
member.exception: This property cannot be set after adding the first image.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder
member.summary: The LZW Encoder based on the specification as per chapter 22 and Appendix F in https://www.w3.org/Graphics/GIF/spec-gif89a.txt The detailed LZW algorithm is written here: http://giflib.sourceforge.net/whatsinagif/lzw_image_data.html

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder.CodeTable
member.summary: Provides the LZW code table implementation. It has been refactored to use open addressing double hashing instead of a regular Dictionary. Some implementation ideas were inspired by Kevin Weiner's Java encoder from here: http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/2D-Graphics-GUI/AnimatedGifEncoder.htm Basically it uses a variant of Knuth's algorithm along with G. Knott's relatively-prime secondary probe.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder.CodeTable.tableSize
member.summary: A prime that provides about 80% occupancy in the code table considering the max used entries when bit size is 12.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.LzwEncoder.CodeTable.entries
member.summary: Earlier versions used a dictionary as a code table where the key was a span of palette indices. Even with shared underlying buffer memory and optimized GetHashCode/Equals implementation it was much less efficient. Here we can exploit that all prefixes of new codes are already stored so when there is a hash collision we don't need to perform an equality check for the whole segment repeatedly (this is what Dictionary does when there are more entries in the same bucket). Instead, we use double hashing and a match key for equality check: - The primary hash is calculated for the current prefix and is used to select a code table entry - A match key is used for equality check. It is calculated last code + current index combination and is stored along with prefix codes. - If equality check by match key fails (collision), then using a secondary hash to jump from entry to entry. The idea was taken from here: http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/2D-Graphics-GUI/AnimatedGifEncoder.htm

member.summary: Encodes the specified as a multi-layered, single frame GIF image and writes it into the specified , preserving its original color depth.
member.param: The image data to write. Possible alpha pixels might be blended with but otherwise the color depth will be preserved.
The stream to save the encoded animation into.

to allow scanning the whole image for each layers to be able to re-use the local palette of the current layer.
to expand the initial layer area to the local pixels only. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

Colors with alpha (transparency), whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than will be blended with this color during the encoding. The alpha value (Color32.A field) of the specified background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a pixel is considered transparent. If 0, then the final composite image will not have transparent pixels. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginEncodeHighColorImage or EncodeHighColorImageAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to set up cancellation or for reporting progress.

This method produces a GIF image that may have compatibility issues. Though the Image and Bitmap types (at least on Windows) support them as expected as well as applications built on GDI+ (such as Windows Paint), many decoders may treat the result as an animation (including browsers).
remarks.para: If is , then both the processing time and memory usage is higher. It helps to minimize the number of layers of the final image; however, the final image size will not be necessarily smaller, especially for true color images.

If is , then each layer is attempted to be as compact as possible. It allows a very fast processing with lower memory usage. Though it usually produces more layers, the final size will not be necessarily larger, especially for true color images.
remarks.note: You can prequantize true color images using a 16-bit quantizer (with or without dithering) to produce fairly compact, still high color GIF images. For such images the parameter with value typically produces more compact results. You can consider using the Argb1555 quantizer for images with transparency, or the Rgb565 quantizer for non-transparent images.
remarks.para: To encode an Image you can use also the ImageExtensions.SaveAsHighColorGif methods.
To create a multi-layered image completely manually you can create a instance that provides a lower level access.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifEncoder.EncodeHighColorImageAsync(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,System.Byte,KGySoft.Threading.TaskConfig)
member.summary: Encodes the specified as a multi-layered, single frame GIF image asynchronously, ans writes it into the specified , preserving its original color depth.
member.param: The image data to write. Possible alpha pixels might be blended with but otherwise the color depth will be preserved.
The stream to save the encoded animation into.

to allow scanning the whole image for each layers to be able to re-use the local palette of the current layer.
to expand the initial layer area to the local pixels only. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

Colors with alpha (transparency), whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than will be blended with this color during the encoding. The alpha value (Color32.A field) of the specified background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which a pixel is considered transparent. If 0, then the final composite image will not have transparent pixels. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1. The encoding itself cannot be parallelized. The MaxDegreeOfParallelism setting affects only some processing steps if the size of a layer exceeds a threshold.
remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the EncodeHighColorImage method for more details.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling
member.summary: Represents the strategy to be used with frames of different sizes.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.ErrorIfDiffers
member.summary: Specifies that if an input frame has a different size, then an exception should be thrown.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.Center
member.summary: Specifies that smaller or larger frames should be centered. Possibly exceeding areas will be clipped.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationFramesSizeHandling.Resize
member.summary: Specifies that frames should be resized to the actual size of the animation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode
member.summary: Represents the looping mode of an animation.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.PingPong
member.summary: Specifies that added frames should be played back and forth.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.Repeat
member.summary: Specifies that the animation should be looped.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AnimationMode.PlayOnce
member.summary: Specifies that the animation should be played only once.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode
member.summary: Represents the compression behavior of the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.Auto
member.summary: Represents the automatic adaptive mode. The internally used code table might be regularly cleared.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.DoNotClear
member.summary: Indicates that once the internally used code table is full, it is not maintained anymore and all remaining codes are written using 12 bit code size. If codes so far can be re-used, then the result can be more compact than with mode; otherwise, the result can be even longer than in mode. This option might not be tolerated by some decoders.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.DoNotIncreaseBitSize
member.summary: Indicates that all written codes must use the same bit size (3 to 9 bits, depending on palette size). It uses less memory but it may lead to poor compression, especially with palettes using no more than 4 colors.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifCompressionMode.Uncompressed
member.summary: Indicates that the should not use any compression. It uses the least memory but the result can be really long.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod
member.summary: Indicates the way in which the graphic is to be treated after being displayed.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.NotSpecified
member.summary: No disposal specified. The decoder is not required to take any action.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.DoNotDispose
member.summary: Do not dispose. The graphic is to be left in place.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.RestoreToBackground
member.summary: Restore to background color. The area used by the graphic must be restored to the background color. If there is no global palette, or the corresponding image has transparent color, then the virtual screen is always cleared to transparent.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.GifGraphicDisposalMethod.RestoreToPrevious
member.summary: Restore to previous. The decoder is required to restore the area overwritten by the graphic with what was there prior to rendering the graphic.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode
member.summary:
Represents the behavior of ditherers with configurable strength when auto strength is used.
See the Remarks section of the OrderedDitherer.ConfigureStrength method for more details and some examples regarding dithering strength.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode.Default
member.summary: The auto strength mode is determined by the property of the corresponding quantizing session. if it returns , then the default strategy is ; otherwise, it is .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode.Constant
member.summary: Represents an auto strength strategy where strength is calibrated to a fix value that assures that neither the black nor the white colors will suffer from overdithering. This is the default auto strength strategy when quantizing in the sRGB color space and it usually works fine if palette entries are evenly distributed in the sRGB color space.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.AutoStrengthMode.Interpolated
member.summary: Represents an auto strength strategy where strength is calibrated both for white and black colors individually so none of them suffer from overdithering. During dithering the actual applied strength will be a dynamic value for each pixels using interpolation between the white and black strengths based on the pixel brightness. This is the default auto strength strategy when quantizing in the linear color space.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat
member.summary: Represents pixel formats with built-in support. For custom formats you can use the type when applicable.

remarks.note: The enumeration contains all formats that the System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat enumeration also has, though some fields have different values and the matching names do not necessarily represent the same pixel layout either. For example, in this library wide formats, such as , use the full 16 bit per color channel range and the same gamma correction as the 8-bit per channel formats, whereas System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format64bppArgb might represent a different range or gamma correction, depending on the operating system.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat.Undefined
member.summary: The pixel format is undefined.

summary.para: Represents the indexed 1 bit per pixel format. The corresponding color palette can have up to 2 colors.
Bit order: bits are filled up from the most significant bit to the least significant bit within a byte.
Represents the indexed 4 bit per pixel format. The corresponding color palette can have up to 16 colors.
Bit order: even pixels occupy the high bits of a byte, whereas odd pixels are in the low bits.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat.Format8bppIndexed
member.summary: Represents the indexed 8 bit per pixel format. The corresponding color palette can have up to 256 colors.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.KnownPixelFormat.Format16bppGrayScale
member.summary: Represents a 16 bit per pixel grayscale format. The color information specifies 65536 shades of gray.

summary.para: Represents a 16 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 5 bits per pixel and 1 bit is unused.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 5 blue, 5 green, 5 red bits and 1 unused bit. As a binary value a pixel can be specified as 0b_X_RRRRR_GGGGG_BBBBB on little endian CPUs where X is the ignored most significant bit and BBBBB is the blue component at the least significant bits.
Represents a 16 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 5, 6 and 5 bits per pixel, respectively.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 5 blue, 6 green and 5 red bits. As a binary value a pixel can be specified as 0b_RRRRR_GGGGGG_BBBBB on little endian CPUs where BBBBB is the blue component at the least significant bits.
Represents a 16 bit per pixel ARGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 5 bits per pixel along with 1 bit for alpha.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 5 blue, 5 green, 5 red bits and 1 alpha bit. As a binary value a pixel can be specified as 0b_A_RRRRR_GGGGG_BBBBB on little endian CPUs where A is the most significant bit and BBBBB is the blue component at the least significant bits.
Represents a 24 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green and 8 red bits.
Represents a 32 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel. The remaining 8 bits are not used.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green, 8 red and 8 unused bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_XX_RR_GG_BB on little endian CPUs where XX is the unused most significant byte and BB is the blue component at the least significant byte.
Represents a 32 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green, 8 red and 8 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AA_RR_GG_BB on little endian CPUs where BB is the blue component at the least significant byte.

Represents a 32 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 8 bits per pixel. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied, according to the alpha component.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 8 blue, 8 green, 8 red and 8 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AA_RR_GG_BB on little endian CPUs where BB is the blue component at the least significant byte.
Represents a 48 bit per pixel RGB color format where red, green and blue channels use 16 bits per pixel.
Bit order from LSB to MSB: 16 blue, 16 green and 16 red bits.
Represents a 64 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 16 bits per pixel.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 16 blue, 16 green, 16 red and 16 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AAAA_RRRR_GGGG_BBBB on little endian CPUs where BBBB is the blue component at the least significant couple of bytes.

Represents a 64 bit per pixel ARGB color format where alpha, red, green and blue channels use 16 bits per pixel. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied, according to the alpha component.

Bit order from LSB to MSB: 16 blue, 16 green, 16 red and 16 alpha bits. As a hex value a pixel can be specified as 0x_AAAA_RRRR_GGGG_BBBB on little endian CPUs where BBBB is the blue component at the least significant couple of bytes.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary: Represents the preferred working color space for various operations such as alpha blending, measuring distance of colors, interpolation, quantizing, dithering and some other operations. The working color space can be specified independently from the color space of the actual pixel format of an instance.

remarks.para:
The working color space can be specified at various places in KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries:
At the lowest level, you can specify it when blending colors manually, for example by the ColorExtensions.Blend method.
instances have a property, which can be set by the factory methods such as the BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData methods or by the GetReadWriteBitmapData methods for the technology-specific bitmap types. The IBitmapData.WorkingColorSpace property is considered when setting pixels with transparency and the pixel format of the bitmap data does not support transparency so the color has to be blended with IBitmapData.BackColor, or when bitmap data instances are drawn into each other.
The class also has a property, which is used by the and methods.
Quantizers also have their own working color space configuration. You can use the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace and OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace methods to configure the working color space of the built-in quantizers of KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries.
Ditherers may also have specific behavior for the different color spaces. The ditherer implementations in KGy SOFT Drawing Libraries always take the working color space of the corresponding quantizer exposed by the IQuantizingSession.WorkingColorSpace property.

Most common color representations (just like the or types that use 8 bit color channels) use the sRGB color space that has gamma corrected color values. In a color type that uses the sRGB color space the consecutive RGB values don't represent linear light intensity increase. Instead, a gamma correction of approximately = 2.2 is applied to the actual light intensity, so it is adjusted for the perception of the human eye (in fact, the sRGB color space is linear for the darkest values and uses a = 2.4 correction above a threshold limit so the overall average is somewhere around 2.2). This representation helps distributing RGB values so that 50% represents the apparently half-bright tones:

term.div: Grayscale color shades. The difference of RGB values between the neighboring shades is constant in the sRGB color space, resulting an apparently linear gradient with half-gray tones at the middle.

remarks.para: Blending partially transparent (alpha) colors in the sRGB color space ends up in incorrect results, though it is not always obvious. The most apparent incorrect results are for colors that have disjunct RGB values, for which the result is typically too dark.

th.div: Blending in the sRGB color space
Blending in the linear color space

td.div: Result of blending colors in the sRGB color space. The vertical bars are opaque, whereas the horizontal ones have 50% transparency. Blending colors with disjunct RGB components often produce too dark results.
Result of blending colors in the linear color space. The result seems much more natural. Note that horizontal bars still have 50% transparency, though they seem brighter now.

Color hues with alpha gradient. As the image contains transparency the blending with the background is performed by your browser.
(Side note: just like at the grayscale gradient above, the color gradients also have constant RGB differences between the horizontal neighboring pixels in the sRGB color space. The examples below are different only in alpha blending but all of them have the same sRGB color gradients.)
Color hues blended with white background in the sRGB color space. If the alpha image in the row above looks like this, then your browser blends colors in the sRGB color space.
Color hues blended with white background in the linear color space.
Color hues blended with black background in the sRGB color space.
Color hues blended with black background in the linear color space. Note that much more colors are visible in the darker regions.

remarks.para: To blend sRGB colors correctly, the source colors must be converted to the linear color space first, and then the blended result has to be converted back to the sRGB color space. This has an additional cost, which is often omitted even by professional image processing applications, libraries and even by web browsers.
remarks.note: Even though blending in the sRGB color space is not quite correct, some pixel formats are optimized exactly for doing that. With premultiplied sRGB pixel formats sRGB blending is very fast, and forcing color correct blending is particularly expensive. Use such pixel formats only when it is really justified, for example when this is the fastest or default format for a rendering engine (which is almost always the case, including GDI+, WPF, UWP, WinUI, Skia and many other engines). If you want to use color correct blending the best if you use pixel formats with linear gamma (indicated by the property), or for sRGB pixel formats try to avoid premultiplied formats to prevent the overhead of unnecessary conversions back and forth.
remarks.para: When reducing the number of colors to some specified set of colors (either by using a of predefined entries or some custom quantizer function) measuring the distance between colors may return different results depending on the used color space. Looking up for the nearest colors in the sRGB color space tends to turn the darker shades too bright, though the more colors the quantizer uses the less noticeable the difference is.

th.div: Quantizing in the sRGB color space
Quantizing in the linear color space

td.div: Original test image "Girl with a Pearl Earring"
Quantizing by black and white palette in the sRGB color space.
Quantizing by black and white palette in the linear color space.
Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the sRGB color space.
Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the linear color space.
Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the sRGB color space. For more colors the difference is much less noticeable but the background is slightly brighter than in the original image.
Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the linear color space. For more colors the difference is much less noticeable but the background is slightly darker than in the sRGB result.

remarks.para: When quantizing is combined with dithering, the ditherers may also respect the working color space of the quantizers. Similarly to the non-dithered results, the difference between working in the sRGB or linear color space gets less and less noticeable with using more and more colors.

th.div: Quantizing with dithering in the sRGB color space
Quantizing with dithering in the linear color space

td.div: Original test image "Girl with a Pearl Earring"

Quantizing by black and white palette in the sRGB color space using Bayer 8x8 dithering. The result is too bright. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear correct, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by black and white palette in the linear color space using Bayer 8x8 dithering. The result has correct brightness. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear too dark, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the sRGB color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. The result is too bright. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear correct, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by RGB111 palette in the linear color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. The result has correct brightness. Please note though that if your browser resizes the image in the sRGB color space it might appear too dark, in which case make sure you open it in a new tab and set the zoom to 100%.

Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the sRGB color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. The background is slightly brighter than in the original image but due to the number of colors the difference is barely noticeable.

Quantizing by system default 8 BPP palette in the linear color space using Floyd-Steinberg dithering. Due to the number of colors the difference is barely noticeable between the sRGB and the linear result.

remarks.para: When resizing images with some interpolation the working color space may also affect the result. When resizing true color images the difference might be negligible; however, if the source image has only a few colors with high frequency areas (typically dithered images as above) the working color space used for the resizing makes a noticeable difference.

th.div: Resizing in the sRGB color space
Resizing in the linear color space

td.div: Test image "Girl with a Pearl Earring" quantized by RGB111 palette in the linear color space using Bayer 8x8 dithering.

Resizing the quantized image with bicubic interpolation in the sRGB color space. The result is too dark. Ironically, if the source image would have been quantized in the sRGB color space so it was too bright, then the resized result would seem quite correct.
Resizing the quantized image with bicubic interpolation in the linear color space. The result preserved the original brightness.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace.Default

If can represent only single-bit alpha or is an indexed format and the target palette contains a transparent color, then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. Default value: 128.

member.summary: Begins to clone the specified with identical size asynchronously.
member.param: An instance to be cloned.

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

remarks.para: In .NET Framework 4.0 and above you can use also the method.
To get the result or the exception that occurred during the operation you have to call the EndClone method.
This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.

member.summary: Gets the clone of the specified portion of with the specified and color settings asynchronously.
member.param: An instance to be cloned.
The desired pixel format of the result.
Specifies the value of the property of the cloned instance and affects the possible blending operations during the cloning.

If does not support alpha or supports only single-bit alpha, then specifies the color of the background. Source pixels with alpha, which will be opaque in the result will be blended with this color. The Color32.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: The default value of the type, which has the same RGB values as .

If can represent only single-bit alpha or is an indexed format and the target palette contains a transparent color, then specifies a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the result will not have transparent pixels. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.

A that specifies the portion of the to be cloned, or to clone the entire . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The configuration of the asynchronous operation such as parallelization, cancellation, reporting progress, etc. When Progress is set in this parameter, then this library always passes a instance to the generic methods of the IAsyncProgress interface. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous operation. Its result is the new instance that represents the clone of the specified , or , if the operation was canceled and the ThrowIfCanceled property of the parameter was .

remarks.para: This method is not a blocking call even if the MaxDegreeOfParallelism property of the parameter is 1.
remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the method for more details.

does not specify a valid format.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.CopyTo(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadableBitmapData,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IWritableBitmapData,System.Drawing.Point,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer)
member.summary: Copies the into the without scaling and blending. This method works between any pair of source and target s and supports quantizing and dithering. To draw a bitmap data into another one with blending use the DrawInto methods instead.
member.param: The source to be copied into the .
The target into which should be copied.

The target location. Target size will be always the same as the source size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: Point.Empty.

An instance to be used. If not specified, then the copying operation might automatically pick a quantizer based on . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

The ditherer to be used. Might be ignored if is not specified and format has at least 24 bits-per-pixel size. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the BeginCopyTo or CopyToAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: The copied area is automatically clipped if its size or makes it impossible to completely fit in the .

If can represent a narrower set of colors, then the result will be automatically quantized to the colors of the , even if there is no specified. To use dithering a must be explicitly specified though.
If is specified but it uses more/different colors than can represent, then the result will eventually be quantized to , though the result may have a poorer quality than expected.

member.summary: Clips the specified using the specified . Unlike the Clone methods, this one returns a wrapper, providing access only to the specified region of the original .
member.param: The source bitmap data to be clipped.
A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the ReadRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the ReadRaw method. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

A limit of the returned colors. If parameter is , then this parameter is ignored for indexed bitmaps. Use 0 for no limit. This parameter is optional.

to force scanning the actual image content even if the specified is indexed and has a palette. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

remarks.para: Completely transparent pixels are considered the same regardless of their color information.

Every is supported, though wide color formats (, , and ) are quantized to 32 bit during the processing. To get the actual number of colors, which can be accurate even for wide color formats, use the GetColorCount method.

member.summary: Gets the actual number of colors of the specified . Colors are counted even for indexed bitmaps.
member.param: The bitmap, whose colors have to be counted to count its colors.

Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This method uses the bottom-left pixel to determine the background color, which must be completely opaque; otherwise, just an exact clone of will be returned.
This method always returns a new with pixel format.
To attempt to make an transparent without creating a new instance use the MakeTransparent method.
To force replacing even non-completely opaque pixels use the overload instead.

To attempt to make an transparent without creating a new instance use the MakeTransparent method.
To auto-detect the background color to be made transparent use the overload instead.
remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the Clone method with a quantizer created by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.FromCustomFunction method.

A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the ReadRaw/WriteRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the ReadRaw/WriteRaw methods. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

Use the BeginQuantize or QuantizeAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This method quantizes the specified in place (its original content will be overwritten). To return a new instance use the Clone extension method instead.
If the or the palette of is not compatible with the colors of the specified , then the result may not be correct.
If has already the same set of colors that the specified , then it can happen that calling this method does not change the at all.

list.item:
To use predefined colors or custom quantization functions use the static methods of the class.

To use an optimized palette of a specified number of colors adjusted for see the class.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.BitmapDataExtensions.MakeTransparent(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IReadWriteBitmapData)
member.summary: If possible, makes the background of this transparent, taking the bottom-left pixel as the background color. If the does not support transparency, then the pixels that have the same color as the bottom-left pixel will be set to the of .
member.param: The to make transparent.

remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the or (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods for asynchronous call and to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation and for reporting progress.
remarks.para: This method calls the ReplaceColor method internally.
Similarly to the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one uses the bottom-left pixel to determine the background color, which must be completely opaque; otherwise, will not be changed.

Unlike the Bitmap.MakeTransparent method, this one preserves the original . If does not support transparency and cannot set either, then every occurrence of the color of the bottom-left pixel will be changed to the of . To make such bitmaps transparent use the ToTransparent method instead, which returns a new instance with .
To force replacing even non-completely opaque pixels use the overload instead.
remarks.note: Please note that unlike the MakeOpaque method, this one changes exactly one color shade without any tolerance. For any customization use the TransformColors method instead.

If has an indexed and is , then its palette entries are tried to be transformed instead of the actual pixels in the first place (if it is supported by ). To transform the colors of an indexed without changing the palette specify a non- . Transforming the palette is both faster and provides a better result.
The is ignored for s with more than 16 bits-per-pixel and for the format.

member.summary: Clips the specified using the specified . Unlike the Clone methods, this one returns a wrapper, providing access only to the specified region of the original .
member.param: The source bitmap data to be clipped.
A that specifies a region within the .
to dispose when the result is disposed; otherwise, .
member.returns: An that provides access only to the specified region withing the .
member.exception: has no overlapping region with source bounds.

remarks.para: The property of the returned instance can be 0, indicating that the WriteRaw method cannot be used. It can occur if the left edge of the clipping is not zero.

Even if property of the returned instance is a nonzero value it can happen that it is too low to access all columns by the WriteRaw method. It can occur with indexed s if the right edge of the clipping is not on byte boundary.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.GetBrightness(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.Color32,KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.WorkingColorSpace)
member.summary: Gets the brightness of a instance as a byte based on human perception. The component of the specified value is ignored.
member.param: The instance to get the brightness of.

The color space to be used for determining the brightness. If , then the sRGB color space will be used. For performance reasons this method does not validate this parameter. For undefined values the sRGB color space will be used as well.
member.returns: A byte value where 0 represents the darkest and 255 represents the brightest possible value.

remarks.note: This method always returns a gamma corrected result, even if is . To get the brightness in the linear color space use the method instead.

remarks.note: This method always returns a gamma corrected result, even if is . To get the brightness in the linear color space use the method instead.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorExtensions.GetBrightness(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.ColorF)
member.summary: Gets the brightness of a instance as a float value in the linear color space. The component of the specified value is ignored.
member.param: The instance to get the brightness of.

member.summary: Gets whether two instances are equal using a specified .
member.param: The first color to compare.
The second color to compare.
The allowed tolerance for ARGB components.

Specifies a threshold under which colors are considered transparent. If both colors have lower value than the threshold, then they are considered equal. If only one of the specified colors has lower value than the threshold, then the colors are considered different. If both colors' value are equal to or greater than this value, then is applied to the value, too. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.
member.returns: , if the colors are considered equal with the specified ; otherwise, .
