member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData
member.summary:
Represents the raw data of a bitmap. To create a managed instance use the class. To obtain a readable or writable instance for platform specific bitmaps you can either use the specific GetReadableBitmapData, GetWritableBitmapData or GetReadWriteBitmapData extension methods when applicable (see the Remarks section of the namespace for a list about the supported platforms). Otherwise, you can use the members of the class to create a bitmap data for any managed or unmanaged preallocated buffer of any bitmap implementation.
See the Remarks section of the BitmapExtensions.GetReadWriteBitmapData method for details and code samples. That method is for the GDI+ Bitmap type but the main principles apply for all sources.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Height
member.summary: Gets the height of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Width
member.summary: Gets the width of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Size
member.summary: Gets the size of the current instance in pixels.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.PixelFormat
member.summary: Gets a of the current instance.

remarks.para: The value of this property determines how the raw underlying values should be interpreted if the pixels are accessed by the ReadRaw or WriteRaw methods. Otherwise, in most cases using the members of the interfaces derived from the and interfaces work seamlessly.
If this property returns an indexed format (see ), then the property returns a non- value.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.Palette
member.summary: Gets a instance representing the colors used in this if represents an indexed format. For indexed bitmaps property of returns .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.RowSize
member.summary: Gets the size of a row in bytes, or zero, if this instance does not have an actual raw buffer to access.

remarks.para: This property can be useful when accessing the bitmap data by the ReadRaw or WriteRaw methods.
As can represent any custom bitmap data, row size is not guaranteed to be a multiple of 4.

note.para: This property can return 0 if the current instance represents a bitmap data without actual raw data or represents a clipped region where the left edge of the clipping has an offset compared to the original bitmap data.

Even if this property returns a nonzero value, it is possible that raw access does not cover the few last columns. This may occur in case of indexed s if the bitmap data is clipped and the right edge of the clipping does not fall at byte boundary.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.BackColor
member.summary:
When accessing pixels of indexed bitmaps, or setting pixels of bitmaps without alpha support, gets the color of the background. For example, when setting color values with alpha, which are considered opaque, they will be blended with this color before setting the pixel.
See the Remarks section of the GetReadWriteBitmapData extension method for details and examples.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this represents a bitmap with single bit alpha or with a palette that has a transparent color, then gets a threshold value for the Color32.A property, under which the color is considered transparent. If 0, then the pixels to be set will never be transparent.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IBitmapData.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary:
Gets the preferred working color space when dealing with the pixels of this instance. Some operations, such as setting pixels or drawing another bitmap data into this instance consider the value of this property. Operations that use an instance may override the value of this property.
Default value if not implemented: . (Only in .NET Core 3.0/.NET Standard 2.1 and above. In earlier targeted frameworks this member must be implemented.)

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.
remarks.para: For implementations the property primarily determines how to blend colors in drawing operations or when this does not support transparency and partially transparent colors are set by the or members. Custom implementations may ignore the value of this property. Some other operations such as cloning, resizing, etc. may also respect the value of this property.

When is , the working color space is chosen based on the context. For example, when setting a pixel using the type, the sRGB blending will be picked (unless has the flag enabled) because it is faster, and it is the default behavior for most applications.
For some operations, such as drawing a bitmap data into another one by the DrawInto methods the working color space is determined by the of the target bitmap data.

When using a quantizer for some operations, it may override the value of this property. As quantizers are limited to the 32 bit ARGB color space, the built-in implementations in this library also use sRGB blending by default but you can override it by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace and OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.ConfigureColorSpace methods.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitherer.InitializeReliesOnContent
member.summary: Gets whether Initialize relies on the actual content of the source to be dithered.

remarks.para: This property should return , if Initialize method relies on the exact content to be dithered in order to make the GetDitheredColor method work properly.

If this property returns , then Initialize will be called with an instance, whose and properties can be used but the actual content might be different from the one will be used when calling the GetDitheredColor method.

The return value of this property may affect the performance of some drawing operations where returning forces the source and target images to be blended together before dithering the result, while returning allows the ditherer to be initialized with the source image and let the GetDitheredColor method to be called with colors that are blended on-the-fly during the dithering.

The to which the dithering should be applied.

Contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An instance that can be used to dither the result of the specified applied to the specified .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitheringSession
member.summary: Represents a disposable dithering session returned by the IDitherer.Initialize method that is used to dither the result of a quantizing session for a specific source.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IDitheringSession.IsSequential
member.summary: Gets whether this ditherer allows only sequential processing (line by line). Even returning does not guarantee that every pixel will be queried. It just enforces that queried rows are processed sequentially.
member.value: If , then the GetDitheredColor method will be called sequentially for each queried pixels. If , then the GetDitheredColor method can be called concurrently for any pixels.

The y-coordinate of the pixel to be dithered represented by the specified .

member.summary: Gets the number of color entries in the current .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IPalette.BackColor
member.summary: Gets the background color. If a lookup operation is performed with a color whose Color32.A field is equal to or greater than , and there is no exact match among the entries of this , then the color will be blended with this color before performing the lookup.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IPalette.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this has a transparent entry, then gets a threshold value for the Color32.A field, under which lookup operations will return the first transparent color in the palette.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IPalette.IsGrayscale
member.summary: Gets whether the palette consists of grayscale entries only.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IPalette.HasAlpha
member.summary: Gets whether the palette contains at least one entry that is not fully opaque.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IPalette.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary: Gets the preferred color space when this instance performs blending and measuring distance when looking for a nearest color.

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.
remarks.para: If the value of this property is , then the sRGB color space is used.
If this palette uses a custom nearest color lookup, then it depends on the custom function whether it considers the value of this property.
remarks.note: Please note that palette entries themselves always represent sRGB color values, regardless the value of this property.

Represents a quantizer that can be used to reduce the number of colors of an image.
For built-in implementations see the and classes.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer.PixelFormatHint
member.summary: Gets a that is compatible with this . It is recommended to return the format with the lowest bits-per-pixel value that is still compatible with this instance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizer.InitializeReliesOnContent
member.summary: Gets whether Initialize relies on the actual content of the source to be quantized.

remarks.para: This property should return , if Initialize method relies on the exact content to be quantized in order to generate a palette and make the GetQuantizedColor method work properly.

If this property returns , then Initialize will be called with an instance, whose and properties can be used but the actual content might be different from the one will be used when calling the GetQuantizedColor method.

The return value of this property may affect the performance of some drawing operations where returning forces the source and target images to be blended together before quantizing the result, while returning allows the quantizer to be initialized with the source image and let the GetQuantizedColor method to be called with colors that are blended on-the-fly during the quantization.

Contains information for asynchronous processing about the current operation. This parameter is optional.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession
member.summary: Represents a disposable quantizing session returned by the IQuantizer.Initialize method that is used to quantize (reduce the colors) of a specific source.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.Palette
member.summary: Gets the palette containing the colors of the quantized result. Expected to be called if the target of the quantization is indexed. Typical indexed pixel formats contain no more than 256 colors; however, it is allowed to return a bigger . If the corresponding returns a non-indexed pixel format in its property, then this property can return .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.BackColor
member.summary:
Gets the background color for this . When the GetQuantizedColor is called with a color with alpha, which is considered opaque, then it will be blended with this color before quantizing.
See also the Remarks section of the property for details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.AlphaThreshold
member.summary: If this can produce transparent pixels, then gets the alpha threshold value that can be used to determine whether a color with alpha should be considered transparent or should be blended with .

remarks.para: If this can produce transparent pixels, and GetQuantizedColor is called with a color, whose Color32.A field is lower than the threshold, then the returned color will be transparent.

If this cannot produce transparent pixels, or GetQuantizedColor is called with a color, whose Color32.A field is greater than or equal to the threshold, then the returned color will be will be blended with before quantizing.
If is 0, then the quantized color will never be transparent.
If is 255, then only fully opaque colors will not be considered transparent.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.IsGrayscale
member.summary:
Gets whether this works with grayscale colors. Its value may help to optimize the processing in some cases but it is allowed to return always .
Default value if not implemented: . (Only in .NET Core 3.0/.NET Standard 2.1 and above. In earlier targeted frameworks this member must be implemented.)

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.IQuantizingSession.WorkingColorSpace
member.summary:
Gets the preferred working color space of this instance. If this quantizing session is used by a ditherer, then implementations may also respect the value of this property.
Default value if not implemented: . (Only in .NET Core 3.0/.NET Standard 2.1 and above. In earlier targeted frameworks this member must be implemented.)

remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the enumeration for details and image examples about using the different color spaces in various operations.

Gets the quantized color of the specified . If property has non- return value, then the result color must be a valid entry.
See also the Remarks section of the property for details.
member.param: The original color to be quantized.
member.returns: The quantized color.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer
member.summary: Represents a quantizer that can generate an optimized set of colors best matching to the original image. Use the static methods to retrieve an instance. For using predefined colors see the class.

remarks.para: The class can be used to reduce colors of an using a palette of up to 65536 colors where the palette entries are optimized for the quantized image. Though more than 256 colors are supported, the typical goal of palette optimization is to adjust the colors for an indexed pixel format. Natively supported indexed formats cannot have more than 256 colors, though you are allowed to create images with custom pixel format by using the BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData methods that have parameters. Please note though that a large palette may have impact on both memory usage and performance.
This class supports palette optimization by three different algorithms (see the Octree, MedianCut and Wu methods)

The following table compares the algorithms supported by the class:
OctreeMedianCutWu
Speed With default settings usually slower than the Wu's algorithm but faster than MedianCut. When using high bit levels and the source is a true color image, then it is generally faster for high requested colors, and can be faster even than Wu's algorithm using the same bit level. In most cases this is the slowest one of the three algorithms, especially for larger images. With default settings this is almost always the fastest one of the three algorithms (still much slower though than the quantizers of the class). When using high bit levels it can be the slowest one for small images and gets to be the fastest one for larger image sizes.
Memory consumption* Generating the palette may consume quite a large amount of memory but it also depends on the number of different colors of the source image and the requested color count. The memory is continuously allocated on demand and in extreme cases it may consume a huge amount of memory. The memory usage can be limited by the ConfigureBitLevel method. The memory usage mainly depends on the image size and somewhat on the requested color count. Quantizing a large image may consume a large amount of memory even if the image itself consist of just a few colors. This quantizer consumes a fairly large fix amount of memory, even if the source has few colors and the requested color count is small. Most of the memory is allocated at once, regardless of the image size or its actual colors, and a smaller portion is allocated dynamically, which depends on the number of requested colors. On platforms where available, array pooling is used, which releases the used memory only after a while if the buffers are not re-used within a time interval. The memory usage can be adjusted by the ConfigureBitLevel method.
Quality
Usually poorer quality for smaller palettes (below 16 colors).
Banding may appear in images with large low-frequency areas (eg. sky or water in photos).
Balanced quality for larger palettes and photo-like images.
Usually better quality for smaller palettes.t
Excellent, nearly banding-free results with images with large low-frequency areas (eg. sky or water in photos).
May provide poorer quality for small areas with unique colors (eg. a smaller human face in a large photo).
Usually very good quality even for smaller palettes.
Banding may appear in images with large low-frequency areas (eg. sky or water in photos). By default, banding may appear for monochromatic images even if the requested number of colors would allow a banding-free result but this can be configured by the ConfigureBitLevel method.
Very good quality for photo-like images, especially if the image has no homogeneous low-frequency areas.
*Memory consumption mentioned in the table affects palette generation only. That occurs when the IQuantizer.Initialize method of an instance is called. As soon as this method returns with an instance, the memory mentioned in the table can be reclaimed (which does not necessarily happen immediately on platforms that support array pooling, which is utilized by the Wu's algorithm).
On the other hand, the can also consume a large amount of memory during the quantization because its caches the quantization results of the source image pixels, though this caching does not depend on the chosen algorithm and the used memory can also be reclaimed when the is disposed.
Keeping a reference to an consumes almost no memory when there is no active quantization session in progress.

The following table compares the results of the instances returned by the Octree, MedianCut and Wu methods. For better comparison none of the images are dithered in the examples, though the visual quality can be improved by using dithering. See the , , and classes for some built-in implementations.
Original image
Quantized image
Color hues with alpha gradient
Octree algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
MedianCut algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Wu's algorithm, 256 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Information icon with transparency
Octree algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
MedianCut algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Wu's algorithm, 4 colors, silver background, zero alpha threshold
Octree algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. Banding appeared in the result.
MedianCut algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. Practically there is no banding in the result.
Wu's algorithm, 256 colors, black background, alpha threshold = 128. A slight banding can be observed, as if the source image had been prequantized by the PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb1555 quantizer first. You get this result if you use the ConfigureBitLevel method with 5 bits (which is the default for Wu with 256 colors). The banding can be reduced by using higher bit levels, which increases also memory usage and processing time.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.ConfigureBitLevel(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Configures the bit level per color channel to be used while optimizing the palette. If the input image is a monochromatic one, then may determine the bit depth of the result, depending on the used algorithm. Affects the quality, speed and memory usage.
member.param: Specifies the desired bit level. If , then the value is automatically set by the chosen algorithm.
member.returns: An instance that has the specified bit level.
member.exception: must be either , or between 1 and 8.

remarks.para: As a primary effect, determines the upper limit of the possible colors in the generated palette. For example, if is 1, then the result palette will not have more than 8 colors, or when it is 2, more than 64 colors. If you want to quantize an image using the allowed maximum of 65536 colors, then should be at least 6 because 5 allows up to 32768 colors.

When using the MedianCut algorithm, configuring the bit level has no other effects. When using the Octree or Wu's algorithms, determines also the amount of minimum distinguishable monochromatic shades. For example, when is 5, then up to 32 monochromatic shades can be differentiated so close shades might be merged even if the requested number of colors would allow returning all the shades.

For the Octree algorithm the default value is the ceiling of the base 2 logarithm of the requested number of colors (eg. 1 for 2 colors, 8 for 129 or more colors). This is alright for most cases. You can increase the default value if the image has only a few but very close colors or decrease it if the image has so many colors that the quantization would use too much memory.

For Wu's algorithm the default value is 5 for no more than 256 colors (requires about 1.5 MB fix memory) and 6 for more colors (requires about 10 MB). This provides good enough quality in most cases but may cause visible banding if the input image is monochrome. To avoid that you can increase the bit level, which dramatically increases also the memory requirement: 7 bits requires about 80 MB memory, whereas 8 bits demands about 650 MB, regardless of the actual number of colors in the source image.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer
member.summary: Credit to Xiaolin Wu's Color Quantizer published at https://www.ece.mcmaster.ca/~xwu/cq.c This quantizer is mainly based on his code.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.CubicBuffer`1
member.summary: Similar to (it allows both 3D and 1D access) but allows negative indices, which returns default value. The original algorithm uses 33x33x33 arrays, where 0 indices are never set in any dimensions so they always were 0. This was acceptable for the original algorithm but with 8 bit resolution (257x257x257 * sizeof(T)) the waste is much more significant, especially with array pooling, which allocates almost twice as much memory as needed when dimensions are 2^n + 1.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Box.Volume(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.CubicBuffer{System.Int64}@)

member.summary: Computes the sum over a box of any given statistic (floating point version).

member.summary: Computes part of that doesn't depend on , or , depending on .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.sqrTable
member.summary: Just a lookup table for squared values between 0..255

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.m2
member.summary: The squared moment values of color RGB values. After building the histogram by an element of this array can be interpreted as m2[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of c^2*P(c) and after it contains cumulative moments. The strictly taken Bernoulli probability is actually multiplied by image size. In Wu's original algorithm effective histogram elements were in 1.. along each axis, element 0 was just for base or marginal value. Here values are zero-based, but reading -1 index is allowed, which returns zero. Values are floats just because of the possible big ranges due to squared values.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.wt
member.summary: The counts of voxels of the 3D color cubes in each position. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mr
member.summary: The moment values of red color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of r*P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mg
member.summary: The moment values of green color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of g*P(c)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.mb
member.summary: The moment values of green color components. The same applies as for except that after values are interpreted as wt[r, g, b] = sum over voxel of b*P(c)

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.HistogramToMoments(KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext)
member.summary: Computing cumulative moments from the histogram.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Var(KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.OptimizedPaletteQuantizer.WuQuantizer.Box)
member.summary: Compute the weighted variance of a box. Note: as with the raw statistics, this is actually the variance multiplied by image size

member.name: M:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PredefinedColorsQuantizer.Argb8888(System.Drawing.Color,System.Byte)
member.summary: Gets a instance that quantizes colors to the 32-bit ARGB color space.
member.param:
Determines the property of the returned quantizer. Considering that this quantizer can return alpha colors it has effect only when the returned quantizer is used with a ditherer that does not support partial transparency. The Color.A property of the background color is ignored. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which has the same RGB values as .

Specifies a threshold value for the Color.A property, under which a quantized color is considered completely transparent. If 0, then the quantized colors will preserve their original alpha value. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 128.
member.returns: A instance that quantizes colors to the 32-bit ARGB color space.

remarks.para: If is zero, then the returned instance is practically just a pass-through filter in the 32-bit color space and it is effective only for some bitmap data operations (eg. Clone), which could possibly preserve wide color information (s with 48/64 bpp) without specifying a quantizer.
If is not zero, then every partially transparent pixel with lower Color.A value than the threshold will turn completely transparent.
This quantizer fits well for the pixel format.

remarks.para: The returned instance can return up to 2563 (16,777,216) colors. It practically just removes transparency and does not change colors without alpha.
This quantizer fits well for the pixel format.

to map any color directly to an index instead of searching for a nearest color, which is very fast but without dithering may end up in a noticeably poorer result and higher contrast; to perform a lookup to determine nearest colors, which may be slower but more accurate. This parameter is optional.

Colors with alpha (transparency), whose Color.A property is equal to or greater than will be blended with this color before invoking the delegate. The Color.A property of the background color is ignored.

The value that the property of the returned instance will return. This parameter is optional.
Default value: , which is valid only if has the default zero value.

Specifies a threshold value for the Color.A property, under which a quantized color is considered transparent. If 0, then even the completely transparent colors will be blended with before invoking the delegate. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.
member.returns: A instance that quantizes colors using the custom quantizer function specified in the parameter.

remarks.para: The quantizer returned by this method does not have a palette. If you need to create an indexed result using a custom mapping function that uses up to 256 different colors, then create a instance specifying a custom function and call the method instead.

This overload never calls the delegate with a color with alpha. Depending on either a completely transparent color will be returned or the color will be blended with before invoking the delegate. In order to allow invoking with alpha colors use the or overloads instead.

remarks.para: If the of is , or , then this method returns the same quantizer as the Rgb888 method.
If the of is , then this method returns the same quantizer as the Argb1555 method.
If the of is , then this method returns the same quantizer as the Rgb565 method.
If the of is , then this method returns the same quantizer as the Rgb555 method.
If the of is , then this method returns the same quantizer as the Grayscale method.
If the of is an indexed format, then this method returns the same quantizer as the method using the of the specified .

If none of above and the has been created by one of the BitmapDataFactory.CreateBitmapData methods that create bitmap data with custom pixel format, then a special quantizer is returned that produces exactly the same colors as the specified .
Otherwise, this method returns either the same quantizer as the Argb8888 method (if the of supports alpha); otherwise, the same one as returned by the Rgb888 method.
remarks.note: For examples see the Examples section of the mentioned methods above.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo
member.summary: Represents a pixel format in a technology-agnostic way. Can be used to specify custom pixel formats for the CreateBitmapData method overloads with a parameter.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets or sets the bits per pixel value of this . Supported range is 1..128 (or 1..16 for formats). Typical values are powers of two but any value is supported.
member.exception: When setting this property, must be between 1 and 128.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.HasAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format has an alpha channel (transparency). For formats this property can be because alpha support is determined by the current palette. Setting this property to resets also the and properties.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.Indexed
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format is an indexed one. An indexed format is not expected to have more than 16 (up to 65536 color entries).
member.value:
If , then pixel data represent entries instead of direct colors.
If , then pixel data represent specific colors.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.Grayscale
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format is a grayscale one. For formats this property can be because grayscale nature is determined by the current palette. Setting this property for non-indexed custom grayscale formats helps to auto select the preferable strategy for some operations such as dithering.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.HasPremultipliedAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format uses premultiplied alpha. Setting this property to sets also the property.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.HasSingleBitAlpha
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format supports single-bit alpha only (a pixel is either completely transparent or completely opaque). Setting this property to sets also the property. It is not mandatory to set this property for custom single-bit alpha formats but it helps optimizing some drawing operations.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.LinearGamma
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the represented pixel format has linear gamma. For formats this property should be because it can be configured at the constructors and factory methods whether the palette should work in the linear color space. If the IBitmapData.WorkingColorSpace property returns , then the value of this property may affect the selected color space of some operations.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormatInfo.IsCustomFormat
member.summary: Gets whether the represented pixel format is a custom one. That is, when this was not instantiated by its constructor with a parameter or one of its properties have been set since then.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.Imaging.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace provides advanced imaging functionality such as low-level bitmap data access for any pixel format, interfaces for quantization and dithering along with some built-in implementations, etc.
See the Remarks section of the namespace for details about the available KGy SOFT Drawing packages and their covered namespaces.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels
member.summary: Represents the RGB color channels when manipulating images.

member.summary: Represents none of the color channels.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.R
member.summary: Represents the Red color channel.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ColorChannels.G
member.summary: Represents the Green color channel.

member.summary: Represents various drawing operations to indicate the current operation when reporting progress using an IAsyncProgress implementation. This library always uses the type as a type argument when calling the New<T>(T, int, int) method.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.DrawingOperation.ProcessingPixels
member.summary: Represents an operation that processes pixels. An more complex async method may perform multiple processing operations one after another.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode
member.summary: Represents the scaling mode when an image needs to be resized.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Auto
member.summary: Represents an automatically selected scaling mode based on source/target sizes providing the best quality. In practice, the scaling mode is selected if either the width or height is enlarged, and the scaling mode, if there is shrinking in both dimensions. If source and target sizes are the same, then is selected.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.NoScaling
member.summary: Represents no scaling. When source and target sizes are different, then clipping might occur.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Represents the nearest neighbor scaling mode, which always selects the closest pixel when scaling. Apart from this is the fastest scaling mode but provides the poorest quality.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Box
member.summary: Represents box scaling mode. When downscaling, the pixels will average. When upscaling, the result is identical to .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Bilinear
member.summary: Represents a 2-dimensional linear interpolation scaling mode. It is among the faster scaling techniques but it provides an acceptable quality only if the difference between the source and target size does not exceed 25%.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Bicubic
member.summary: Represents the bicubic interpolation. It both preserves sharpness and reduces artifacts quite well. This is the default scaling mode when downscaling images.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Lanczos2
member.summary: Represents the resampling algorithm suggested by Kornl Lnczos using a kernel radius of 2 pixels. It both preserves sharpness and reduces artifacts quite well. When downscaling, acts also as a low-pass filter. The result is usually similar to the bicubic filter.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Lanczos3
member.summary: Represents the resampling algorithm suggested by Kornl Lnczos using a kernel radius of 3 pixels. It is among the slower filters and it tends to increase the sharpness of the original image.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Spline
member.summary: Represents the spline cubic interpolation. It provides smooth results but it tends to overly blur the details.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.CatmullRom
member.summary: Represents the Catmull-Rom cubic interpolation. Similarly to the bicubic interpolation it preserves sharpness quite well without producing strong artifacts.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.MitchellNetravali
member.summary: Represents the Mitchell-Netravali cubic interpolation. Usually it produces very good results. This is the default scaling mode when upscaling images.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Drawing.ScalingMode.Robidoux
member.summary: Represents the Robidoux cubic interpolation. It produces a very similar result to the Mitchell-Netravali interpolation.
